newsitem.title: USA: Chrysler rises, lifting auto sector.
newsitem.headline: Chrysler rises, lifting auto sector.

text.p: Chrysler Corp surged after the automaker posted surprisingly strong third-quarter earnings on Monday, pointing to a rich product mix and robust production, which came in 17,000 vehicles higher than the firm's own forecasts.

Chrysler shares jumped 1-1/8 to 32-7/8 after the release of its quarterly profits of $1 a share excluding extraordinary items, blowing past Wall Street estimates of $0.71 a share, according to First Call Corp.
Ford Motor Co shares rose 1/2 to 32-5/8 and General Motor Shares rose 1-1/2 to 51-5/8.

"I think it was all in the sales mix," Burnham Securities analyst David Healy said of Chrysler's strong performance. "They've raised prices and the mix has shifted to trucks. They're selling not so many Neons and a lot more Jeep Grand Cherokees and Town & Country minivans."

Dean Witter Reynolds Inc auto analyst Kenneth Blaschke agreed: "It was a solid quarter because of the higher production and a strong mix. The company's selling more fully loaded and higher end vehicles."

Blaschke said the earnings surprise and statements by Chrysler executives that fourth quarter incentives will remain flat with the third quarter level of $685 per vehicle, led Dean Witter to raise its 1996 full year earnings estimate for Chrysler to $5.14 from $4.74.
He also said Dean Witter's 1997 Chrysler estimate was raised to $5 from $4.25 because the automaker disclosed that it will add 190,000 units worth of truck production capacity next year.
